segments.text: Worked out.
Got an hour's tape?
It's an hour and a half.
45 minutes each side.
What kind of information do you need?
Well, first of all, you know, name rank and stuff.
I can give you that.
My name is Rod Huddleston.
Actually, Rodney.
I go by Rod.
I was...
I served in Vietnam as a sergeant.
Do you really want my serial number?
I've still remembered it.
You still remember your serial number?
Yes, I do.
You never forget that.
Back in those days, we didn't use the Social Security number.
They gave us a service number.
Actually, they called it a serial number.
What were your reasons for joining the military?
I joined during the Cuban crisis when President Kennedy...
And the going zone in Cuba, we at that time all thought we were going to war.
It looks very real.
I was in college at the time at California Polytechnic, Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo.
I was a freshman in college.
Not doing exceptionally well in my grades.
I thought that was probably the lesser of two evils.
Besides...
If you'd like to, we can start a tab if you'd like.
No, it's paying out.
All right.
But I joined.
That was the reason I joined.
Myself and several people went down at the same time.
In fact, the induction center in Los Angeles, when we joined, was about six blocks long for volunteers.
So I was a volunteer.
And you volunteered in what?
That was in 1963.
Actually, the Cuban crisis was over by the time I actually went in.
I had signed up during the Cuban crisis and then there was a waiting period before they would come and, you know, you'd have to get your physical and pull out the papers and so forth.
By the time I actually went in was in January of 63 and the Cuban crisis had passed by that time.
Oh, we were still excited, but the Navy had already blockaded Cuba.
But I had already joined, so I went into MCRD, Marine Corps Recruit Depot, San Diego.
I was there for
eight weeks, and then another eight weeks of training at Camp Pendleton, ITR, they called it, Infantry Training Regiment.
And then they gave me a 15-day leave, and I came back and took advanced combat training.
And while I was in advanced combat training, there was some kind of a problem in the demilitarized zone in Korea along the 38th parallel, so they
ended our training rather abruptly and in the middle of the night they took us all down to San Diego by truck and bus and every other conveyance.
We got on several large ships and we went to sea.
And some were in the course of things.
We thought we were going to Korea but we ended up debarking in Hawaii.
I got off at Hawaii and
waited in what they call a staging battalion, which is where they put you when they're waiting to determine where you go for a few days.
I don't remember how long.
It's been too many years ago.
Then I was assigned to the 1st Marine Brigade at Kaneohe Bay on Oahu as part of a replacement group.
And that became my unit.
The 1st Marine Brigade
had as its major infantry arm the 4th Marine Regiment.
It also had, because it was a brigade and it was the major strike unit in the Pacific Theater at that time, for instant response, we had our own artillery and armor and air support.
When the Vietnam situation came about, they moved us to Okinawa first.
And I went to Okinawa with the 4th Marine Regiment.
more combat training there, and it was some rather different type of training than we'd ever had before.
We all knew that something was up, but we didn't really know what was up.
They were very secretive.
In fact, most of us in those days never heard of Vietnam.
We had barely heard of it in the papers we were beginning to more and more.
The training routine was 4 o'clock in the morning to 10 o'clock at night.
A lot of bayonet work, a lot of hand-to-hand combat, a lot of demolitions, a lot of ambush drills.
We had counterinsurgency training, guerrilla warfare training.
We finally loaded ship off of the capital of Okinawa was Naha, or is Naha, I should say.
We went aboard ships there.
We went into the South China Sea.
And we were afloat for about three months, waiting for the administration to make up its mind.
After three months on a troop ship, you're ready to invade anywhere just to get off the ship.
Long lines all day long, standing.
They get you up at about 4 o'clock in the morning, and you stand in line for hours until you can eat breakfast.
And when you get out of what they call on a ship a galley,
You have a few minutes to look out to sea, and then they put you back in a line again for your midday meal.
And then after your evening meal, it's sleep for a few hours and get up again and start the whole thing over.
There wasn't really even room for us to do much physical exercise.
There were so many troops on the ship and so much equipment.
We were literally like sardines.
We floated until the decision was made to apparently land combat troops in Vietnam, the 4th Marine Regiment.
And the 3rd Marine Regiment and the 9th Marine Regiment, which were the other two regiments compounding the 3rd Marine Division, were the first combat troops to go in to Vietnam.
Now, there had been advisors and some air units that arrived before us.
But as far as actual combat infantry commands, those three regiments were the first to go in.
The combat team that I was with, they took one battalion out of our regiment
leaving the 2nd Battalion and the 3rd Battalion.
Then they attached another battalion from the 3rd Marines to us, which was 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines.
We went ashore May 7, 1965, a place called Chu Lai, South Vietnam, with three infantry battalions, 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines, 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines, 3rd Battalion, 4th Marines.
We had as our direct mission to provide security for a airfield that was being built by the Seabees.
Seabees is Civilian Construction Battalion of the Navy.
We were told originally that we would be in this then Republic of South Vietnam for 10 days, roughly, to lend support to the government of South Vietnam to try to stabilize it.
They were having some difficulties, which became very obvious later.
We went ashore expecting a combat situation.
We were fully combat loaded.
By that I mean men had been issued ammunition for their weapons.
We had grenades.
We had prior techniques.
We had explosives.
We went ashore expecting a fight.
They had told us that the beaches we were landing on would be defended and hostile.
That proved not to be true.
The only South Vietnamese we saw were a group of young women
Six or seven had a large banner that said, welcome Marines.
There was no shooting when we went ashore the first day.
It was the worst thing that we experienced was the heat.
We weren't used to it.
Not that the ships had been that much more comfortable, but when we landed, we were carrying our full field transport packs.
They had given us food, ammunition, other supplies that would supposedly last us 10 days.
And we also had gas masks, shelter halves,
Flak jackets, which is what they call... Steel, steel jackets.
Yes, steel coverable canvas.
Actually, it was a Teflon nylon plate inside a jacket and the little, what they call drawers or panties to protect you in that area.
A lot of weight to lug around.
When we landed, it was 125 degrees in July.
Humidity runs around 100% in the tropics.
The first day we went ashore, we didn't go inland.
We just stayed on the beach, and we got ourselves together, and we helped the Navy in landing supplies, bringing support equipment ashore.
The second day, we started marching inland.
My particular unit, they divided battalions up into companies.
Each company was given a mission.
We had to secure a hill west of the airstrip.
And I don't recall the name of the hill now.
It had a number, I think.
Marching inland to the hill was about five miles from the beach.
We lost our first man that day.
He wasn't in any activity.
He died of heat exhaustion.
We were without water.
We landed, each of us carrying two full canteens, quart size.
Most of us drank all of our water the first day ashore.
They didn't resupply us with water that night or the next day because all the water had to come from the ships.
And all of the Marines and the Seabees and the various supporting groups that were in support of us, there was a lot of men ashore, I think around 10,000 is the figure I heard.
The ships could not distill enough water and transport enough to all the various units to keep up with the demand.

Of course, we were supposed to be on water rations, and each man was only supposed to drink so much at a time, but that was really no problem because for the second day, none of us had any water anyway.
We had a kid in my platoon started suffering from heat exhaustion, and we tried our best to cool him, but there was nothing we could do.
The helicopters from the ships, we called for medevac, but for some reason, there was a mess up in communications.
They didn't get there in time.
That was all of a shock to us because we were prepared, I think, in our mind for fighting, but we weren't prepared for seeing people die of heat exhaustion.
It was kind of a shock, particularly someone that we'd been with and known for quite some time.
After that, things got kind of blurry in my mind, and I don't know from what happened from one day to the next.
I know we went out to the hills.
and we dug in.
We didn't have concertina wire in the beginning.
The supplies hadn't got on the beach or they couldn't get them to us.
There were not a lot of trucks there at that time or jeeps.
We had just gone ashore basically with infantry and very little in the way of support.
So we just dug holes.
We didn't have sandbags to fill, to make sandbag bunkers.
We just piled up a parapet of earth around our fighting holes.
For the first few days,
Actually, I guess it would be the better part of the first week.
There was absolutely no enemy activity.
There was a lot of shooting at night.
It's because we were nervous, green, inexperienced, not tried combat veterans, and we were shooting at shadows.
We didn't know when the enemy would attack, and we kept seeing signs of enemy activity.

By that, I mean we sent out patrols every day, and we would see evidence of what we thought where the enemy had been in villages, and villagers were telling us that the Viet Cong had been there, but we hadn't come across them yet.
None of us had seen them.
We found...
evidence of campsites.

We found places where it looked like maybe defensive positions had been made at one time or another that may or may not have been Viet Cong, but everything we saw in those days we thought was Viet Cong.
That's the nature of inexperienced troops.
The first actual attack we had was a rather minor thing.
It wasn't really a battle at all.
I'm not even sure it could be classified as a skirmish.
The Gulf Company 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines was attacked on an outpost by small arms.
It was a probing attack.
There was a couple of men wounded.
I don't think anybody was killed at that time.
A couple of days later, we had a patrol that was fired upon, sniper, and one man was killed.
I remember that.
I didn't know him, but we heard about it.
Bit by bit, our contact with the enemy started increasing, and it started mainly in the evening.
We started getting very nervous at night.
When the sun would go down, we had to start watching for attacks, grenade attacks.

snipers would usually operate best right around twilight sunrise or sunset when people were relaxed getting up to stretch to go to the bathroom things like that and we started losing a lot of people to sniper fire and that they were doing more danger to us than we were to them at that time we weren't very successful at taking out the enemy we hadn't learned their how to how to deal with them i was involved my own personal
contact came after I'd been ashore for maybe a month.
I'd heard and I'd seen a lot, but I had never fired my weapon in combat, I guess you'd say, or hostile.
I was leading a patrol.
At that time, I was a corporal.
I was with Fox Company, 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines.
I was given an assignment on one morning to take out a fire team, which was four men.
to go down along the coast about a mile to go inland to a village, I don't remember the name of it, which was about a mile from the coast, and then to come back
and make it like a big square and to check this area out.
Yeah, it was a reconnaissance patrol to see if there was any activity in that area.
We ran patrols constantly, and there were different patrols covering different parts of the map to make sure that everything was clear.
Again, our major job was to provide security for the airfield that was being built at Chu Lai.
And all this time that we had been there, the CBs were working 24 hours a day, hauling dirt, putting in steel mesh parts to build this runway.
On this patrol that I was speaking of, we went out, we were walking along the coast.
It was a trail on, I guess it was like cliffs.
You could look down on inlets of the water, maybe 100 feet below us.
And there was, I recall, some fishermen.
And they had little round boats, one-man boats.
The boats were maybe eight foot across, all black.
They would take a framework of,

bamboo and then stretch canvas or something over it real tight and then tar it so that it was it would float and they used these as one-man fishing boats and they were right in this inlet along the coast and we saw these people down there didn't pay very much attention to them all at once we were spread out probably 20 30 meters between each man it sounded like bees
going past my head.
And then I heard a pop.
It was at a distance and with a surf down below.
It didn't sound exactly right, but it was a definite pop, pop, pop kind of a noise.
And I guess instinctively, I don't know, we all just hit the ground.
We threw ourselves to the ground even before we returned fire.
Not very good troops, but we were being shot at.
First time we'd been shot at.
And we returned fire.
We were at that time equipped with M14 rifles.
which was firing 7.62 millimeter standard NATO round.
We, being nervous, had all set our rifles with a selector on full automatic.
We all emptied a 20-round magazine in just a matter of seconds into those little boats.
I don't know exactly which one of them was doing the firing.
If all of them were or one of them was, I'm not sure.
I think I saw one person with what might have been a carbine, which is a preferred rifle at that time for the Viet Cong.
It's a light, small weapon.
American-made carbine, World War II vintage carbine.
.30 caliber.
No, not a machine gun.
Usually semi-automatic.
It's a lightweight weapon, and the Vietnamese loved them.
I guess we sold them.
There's War Surfer or something, because they had plenty of them.
This was before we started seeing a lot of AK-47s.
This was the beginning.
Anyway, we fired into this group of fishermen, and
Kind of strange at the time, suddenly realized that either I or all of us together or some of us had killed a bunch of people because they were all dead, kind of floating in the surf.
And we splintered their boats.
We went on the rest of the patrol.
We called in on a PRC-6 radio we were carrying what had happened, and they told us to continue the patrol, and we did.
They sent an H-34 helicopter out and circled over the scene.
We saw them from a distance.
They circled a half a dozen times around, then they flew back.
We finished the patrol.
We came in.
The company commander called me up, had a bunch of questions.
I gave my report.
It was kind of anti-climatic for my first experience in combat.
That was really all there was to it.
After that, things just kind of gradually increased in their tempo.
The first major operation that our battalion was involved in was called Starlight.
And it was to the south of Chiuli on a peninsula.
We were operating in conjunction with the 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines, and our sister battalion, the 3rd Battalion, 4th Marines.
Most of the infantry companies of all the battalions were involved, along with some naval forces in cooperation offshore.
This is supposed to be the first major battle.
The Marines finally meet the VFBF.
This is the first one that I was involved with, and I think it was the first one of the war, Operation Starlight.
And it went wrong from the beginning.
It was supposed to be a hammer and anvil attack.
By that, I mean that...
We were supposed to have some forces push the enemy forces into a stationary ambush and either capture or annihilate the enemy.
By this, we had landed by sea one battalion of Marines, 3rd Battalion, 3rd, had come in and had dug in along the coast to cut off the enemy's exit from that direction.
Another battalion went overland by six-by trucks and Amtrak's.
and they pushed in from the land.
My battalion was dropped in by what we called then vertical envelopment by helicopter assault.
Down the rope?
Down the rope.
Some of the helicopters landed.
Others we repelled out of them to get in.
The first units repelled.
Later, it was just get out of the helicopter any way you could.
Unfortunately, the LZ, that stands for landing zone, they picked it right in the headquarters area of the 1st Regiment of the North Vietnamese Army, NVA regulars.
And they weren't Viet Cong.
They were uniformed professional troops equipped with Russian or Soviet-made weapons.
You saw his uniform when he killed him?
Yeah, we saw plenty of them.
When I was coming out of the helicopter, my particular chopper was coming down.
I saw across the field a helicopter explode in the air and bodies falling.
Another helicopter was laying on the ground burning.
We jumped out.
probably eight foot above the ground, jumped into mud, landed in a rice paddy.
Fire was coming all over the place.
We were caught in what's called grazing fire by heavy machine guns.
Most of my platoon was decimated within seconds.
Squads were completely annihilated.
People were just finding people from every kind of outfit and trying to form some kind of resistance.
We had fire coming into us from the back, the front, and both sides.
We were caught in a criss-cross fire.
Two rifle companies were wiped out in about three minutes, something like 400 casualties.
We finally consolidated.
groups of us survivors behind dikes and started returning fire and trying to get some type of a fire superiority.
That's the trick in combat.
If you can get fire superiority, you can overcome an enemy position.
Most of our radio men have been killed.
We couldn't find any PRC-10 radios, which is a heavy radio.
We had a few PRC-6s, but they didn't have the range to reach the other troops that were from the other direction.
This is a large peninsula.
We could not reach any air units.
Most of our forward air observers had been killed or their radios destroyed.
We had no artillery that we could not reach by radio.
We had no artillery support that we could reach.
We didn't have any air support that we could reach.
So we were totally on our own and cut off for most of that evening.
That evening, only darkness saved us.
That's the only thing.
We managed to consolidate.
We tried to drag our wounded in as best we could.
had very few corpsmen left.
We had very few officers left.
We had very few NCOs left.
It was just an assemblage of people from Gulf Company, Hotel Company, Foxtrot Company, Echo Company, H&S Company.
That's headquarters and support.
Wherever you could find a Marine, we were just getting together in groups.
Five men here, half a dozen men there, three men somewhere else.
We were trying to set up a defensive perimeter as best we could.
The old man, the battalion commander, was still alive, fortunately.
His name was Lieutenant Colonel J.R. Fisher.
We called him Bull Fisher.
And he's probably the person most deserving for saving what was left of the battalion.
He was a Korean War and a World War II veteran, and he managed to bring some type of organization out of shambles.
The next morning, we were organized to the point that we launched a limited offensive to try to get to a better position, to get out of that area where we were.
It was an attack launched on our bellies.
We didn't go running and charging on our feet like you see in the movies.

We went forward by skirmishers, one man at a time, two men covering one, leapfrogging, getting behind trees, moving up behind bushes, trying to get fields of fire, trying to find cover and concealment.
we finally were able to get to some high ground.
In the meantime, our sister battalion, third battalion, fourth marines was trying to come to our rescue.
Aircraft observers had noted by being able to see what was happening, even though we couldn't talk to them, they had given their reports.
Tanks came in, but the tanks were knocked out by 57 millimeter anti-tank guns of the North Vietnamese.
It was very limited maneuverability for the tanks because of the mud and the rice paddies.
Finally, about midday, phantom deuces from carriers offshore came in.
That was the first time that napalm was used in the Vietnam War.
They dropped, they repeated napalm attacks on the enemy position.
The napalm broke their resistance.
We attacked on line, formed a skirmish line, and assaulted behind the napalm.
We linked up with 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines on the beach towards evening.
We captured 600 and something enemy and killed about 1,400.
We consolidated the next two days, cleaning up, picking up wounded, burying, and trying to reorganize what was left of our units.
That was my first major operation.
After that, we considered that we were veterans.
We all suddenly grew up overnight.
And then from that time on, the operations just became one after another.
You'd go out on an operation.
And I remember writing home to my folks that I would be going on another operation.
And if I came back, I'd write them when I got back.
It got to be where you didn't want to make friends anymore because people didn't last that long.
Did you lose most of your men to booby traps and that kind of stuff?
No, most of the men.
Actually, we lost them to everything.
We lost them to sickness.
We started getting sick about this time.
Malaria, dysentery, fever of unknown origins, various kinds, infection.
We were highly susceptible to infections of all kinds.
You'd fall down in bushes, and you'd get cut by thorns, and then your arm or your leg would become infected.
And it was very hard to rid the infection in that area.
And we couldn't stay clean.
And all this time that I'm speaking of, I had not changed my utilities from the day I went ashore.
We had no showers.
We were still on water rations.
Half a canteen per day per man.
That's a half a quart of water in temperatures of 120 plus degrees.
We lost casualties to everything.
Couldn't keep track of it.
We lost casualties to snipers.
We lost casualties to enemy activity.
We lost casualties to sickness.
We lost men to the torments of war.
Some people couldn't take the pressure.
Maybe I shouldn't say that, but I guess that's the truth.
After a while, the outfit was no longer the same outfit that had come from Hawaii.
different group of people.
But the ones that came, pretty soon you got to know them too.
We tried not to make friends, but if somebody stayed around long enough, you'd get friendly with them anyway.
The old timers got to be less and less, but the replacements kept coming.
There wasn't as many as there should have been.
We always were understrength.
Companies that were supposed to be 200 men would operate at about average, I guess, 75 or 80 men.
Battalions that were supposed to be 1,300 would operate at around 600 or 700.
But we did the job.
We kept going.
We marched.
We kept holding the position.
A couple of more operations, and I don't remember their name.
There was one, I do remember one, called Operation Cooperation.
That was kind of a joke.
It was us, between us, the South Vietnamese, which they were trying to work in with our units so that we could train them in our method of fighting.
But this time, Army troops had landed, United States Army.
The 25th Division came over, and I believe at that time that elements of the 1st Air Cav Division had already begun to land, too.

yeah well they were their helicopter assault troops they're the old now cavalry is out of helicopters used to be they were on horses but uh i believe those two divisions along with the fourth division was elements of the fourth division were already landing we had i recall when the army came in
to the Chu Lai area.
I don't remember which units of the Army it was.
They decided to have a cooperative or combined operation between Marines, the United States Army, and South Vietnamese, or what we called ARVN forces, Army of the Republic of South Vietnam.
Operation cooperation was a real big farce.
We spent days and days and days walking through the tulies, just getting hot and mesquite a bit, and never saw hiding the hair of the enemy.
And after about six or seven days of this, nothing to say for it but a lot of sore feet and extremely tired, we finally did come on a village where we were fired upon from a distance.
Each respective service fell back to their own training.
Kind of a beard.
What do you have on top?
I'm fine, thank you.
Anyway, this particular operation, each respective service did their own thing.
When we were fired upon, the South Vietnamese retreated to the rear as fast as they possibly could.
The Army dug in and started calling for air support, and our Marine units attacked, because that's the way we'd been trained.
And naturally, when you're on line and you're not supposed to go forward of the other forces, when we attacked for the advance, we were in front of the Army.
The South Vietnamese, not knowing which way the battle was going, decided to fire upon the Army, and the Army attacked in both directions with air and artillery.
We had an incoming fire on us.
Air strike came in on us then.
One of many.
So the Army separate casualties from the Army?
Oh, yeah.
There was a lot of friendly casualties taken during the war.
It was something that they don't speak of too much in the history books, but many, many men were wounded or killed because of friendly fire, if you want to use that term loosely.
We were many, many times attacked by the United States Air Force.
Not blaming them.
They had an awful hard to tell from way up high who's who on the ground.
But that's just the fortune of war.
We were strafed by the South Vietnamese Air Force.
We were shelled by our own artillery so many times that I thought that we had magnets drawing in their shells.
That just goes along with it.
And I suppose that's probably happened in every war.
It's nothing new.
Anyway, after that, I went ahead and served a half a tour of duty over there at that time.
Well, it was really been more than half.
I served about nine months in Vietnam.
And I got orders, came in, sending me back to Camp Pendleton for further training.
I thought I was out of it for good, but I spent a total of 60 days in Camp Pendleton, and then I was sent back to Vietnam.
And I was sent back to my old outfit, same battalion, same regiment.
However, I was sent to a different company.
I'd been in F Company, or Foxtrot originally, and I was sent back the second time to Echo Company, or E Company.
And I preferred going back to my old outfit.
I was glad that happened.
That wasn't my plan.
That was just luck.
They happened to be in the area, and I was...
I came back in to the right place at the right time.
My outfit moved north from Chu Lai.
I came back in.
They were still at Chu Lai when I got there.
But shortly afterwards, we moved up to Marble Mountain, which is in the area of Da Nang, in the Marble Mountain area.
But this time, the operations had been formed into areas of operation in Vietnam.
We were in the I Corps area, which was Chu Lai north.
And then they had the...
three core areas of Vietnam that it was divided into operational areas.
I Corps would be the same as first core area.
And then they had a second and third core down to the south.
I never saw Saigon.
I never was down in the Mekong River Delta.
I was always north.
I was from Chu Lai north and all the major areas there.
Marble Mountain.
was, like I said, outside of Da Nang.
At Da Nang, we had a big airfield.
We also had a big harbor at Da Nang for shipping.
And the Marble Mountain area was to secure that airfield and that harbor.
We were, at that time, caught up in the Vietnamese Civil War.
Are you running out of tape?
Oh, no.
It's going fine.
I'm going to get someone to pick you up while I was racking it up.
What am I saying?
We were at the Marble Mountain defending Da Nang.
At that time, it's when the Civil War broke out between the South Vietnamese, the Buddhists and the Catholics were fighting out.
We got caught in the middle of that, and my outfit was sent to 3rd MAF Headquarters.

The Marine Corps had been divided into a Marine amphibious force for this time, and it represented the 3rd Marine Division, elements of the 1st Marine Division, with support groups from the Marine Air Wing and...
various armor and artillery units made up the entire 3rd Marine Amphibious Force.
We had at that time about six infantry regiments with other supporting units of Marines.
At 3rd MAF headquarters, we were attacked by the South Vietnamese.
We had orders to try, since they were our allies, not to fire on them.
but to fire over their heads as a warning.
When we took six casualties, six men were wounded.
I think one man was killed when Corsairs attacked us from the South Vietnamese Air Force.
We eventually opened up with our weapons, returned fire, and shot down one plane and damaged another one until they pulled off.
I guess our outfit got a bad reputation or something because they pulled us out of 3rd MAF after that.
We were known to be too radical or rebellious, shooting at the allies.
The South Vietnamese complained about us, shooting down one of their planes.
So they sent us further north.
We went to a place called Dong Ha.
No, I'm wrong.
Fubai first.
Went to Fubai.
Fubai had a little dinky airfield.
It was really nothing more than a cleared off dirt patch.
At Fubai, uh,
We were setting up a major camp.
We didn't know then what it was for, but a lot of artillery, armor, infantry units were building up there.
We made major defensive positions.
Again, there was an airfield at Phu Bai.
We were also defending the main artery on the ground, which was Highway 1, which ran north-south through South Vietnam.
We had several bridges over rivers that we were defending.
We sent out outposts, and we even manned some old French forts for a period of time trying to defend the highway.
We were involved in this time Operation Texas, Operation Dodge City, Operation J.
Operation J was a particularly rough operation.
That involved...
mainly the 4th Marine Regiment, against units of the 242nd B Division in the North Vietnamese Army, and I don't know which regiments it was.
They did a pretty good job of fighting us.
We took quite a few casualties there, but we eventually...
This was the same place where a French battalion was ambushed when the French was there.
They called it the Street of No Joy.
At that time,
I think my company took about 70 casualties on that particular operation.
It lasted about three weeks.
We came in pretty weak, pretty hurt.
And they put us into R&R, in-country R&R, which was a safe area.
They moved us back down to a place north of Da Nang that was supposed to be secure.
We'd been there about three days.
This was after Operation J.
And we were on a hill.
They had showers built there for us.
Even had a little PX truck that came around once a week.
Then we were attacked there.
Supposedly there was friendly forces between us and the enemy, but somehow they got through.
It was a satchel charge attack, came in in the middle of the night.
And after that was over, we were ready to go back to the front, wherever that was.
The rear area wasn't too safe either.
After leaving Da Nang the second time, we went up and started making our major moves towards the Rock Pow and Kam Lo, which later became known as Khe Sanh.
Kam Lo originally was called Artillery City because we started breaking up a lot of big guns, self-propelled 80-inch 155 howitzers, shelling across the DMZ into North Vietnam.
We were trying at this point to
stop movement down the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
And this is a point on the trail where we could reach with the big guns.
Every night we would see Huff the Magic Dragon, as we called it then.
It was a
Well, it wasn't a C-130.
It was a C-47 with a Gatling gun shooting out the side.
You could hear it for miles away.
It kind of made a roaring sound, and you could see it look like Star Trek, just a straight red line with a tracer fire coming down.
We got entertained by this, and then at night, too, the planes would come over dropping photographic flares.
along the Ho Chi Minh Trail, taking pictures.
We ran a lot of patrols, and we had a lot of patrol activity, a lot of skirmishes with patrols.
It was almost a daily occurrence that one of our patrols would run into an enemy patrol and have a little firefight.
We moved up on Operation Hastings.
Things started getting really rough.
We moved up to the rock pile.
The rock pile was a high area right along the DMZ.
It was very rough, and it was really nothing more than a big pile of rocks out of the middle of the jungle.
It had been secured by the enemy because it made an excellent observation post, as well as high ground always is critical for controlling an area of real estate.
Our job at that time was to, what they called a reconnaissance in force, to go in
to see how strong the enemy position was, to probe their lines, and to see what kind of resistance we got.
And then they would determine from that how much strength would be needed to assault and take the position.
The reconnaissance in force got in over its head, as usually happens with reconnaissance in forces, if that's correct grammar.
And once again, my company at this time, E Company, 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines, we got ambushed.
We got held down by heavy fire, same thing as ambush.
And we took a lot of casualties.
F Company pulled us out the next day.
We eventually took the rock pile.
We held that.
We came back from that position.
And during the same operation, K Company, 3rd Battalion, 4th Marines,
was pretty well wiped out.
But we did see something kind of unusual there.
The enemy, I don't know which division of the North Vietnamese Army it was.
Again, we were fighting NVA.
Did you ever run across VC?
Yes, we did.
I haven't mentioned the VC very much.
I don't think very much of them.
I consider them bandits.
That's the way we thought of them.
I don't mind.
The NVA troops were troops.
They were soldiers, as I started to say.
In this particular operation, the NVA was Operation Hastings.
Operation Hastings was designed to stop what we then believed to be a major thrust from North Vietnamese regulars.
Operation Hastings was one of the battles in the Vietnam War of super size.
It involved multiple regiments from both sides.
A regiment numbers around 4,000 men.
By T-O-N-E, our regiments were a little smaller.
We had in this operation the 4th Marines, which is 4th Marine Regiment, the 7th Marines, the 3rd Marines, and some units of the 9th Marines.
I think only one battalion, though.
The 7th Marines was from the 1st Marine Division.
And then, of course, there was various artillery and armored units in support.
We were going up against a division of the North Vietnamese Army.
Their divisions, if I remember correctly,
numbered about five infantry regiments.
Their T.O.
and E. is a little different than ours.
Their battalions and company shrinks were somewhat different.
I believe their regimental size was smaller than our regimental size, although they had more regiments to a division.
They were pretty well equipped.
A typical North Vietnamese soldier wore a green olive drab uniform
but it was of a thinner material than ours.
They had tennis shoes for their footwear.
They had a lightweight helmet that was... Like a pith helmet?
More like a pith helmet, yes.
Okay, that's $150 and $1.
Not exactly in the style of the traditional British pith helmet, but like a pith helmet.
The same type of lightness of weight.
It was round in shape.
Many of them would have a khaki colored belt with a star on their belt buckle.
They had most generally equipped with AK-47 Russian assault rifles, although some were made in Czechoslovakia and Poland.
A lot of them were Chinese, too.
as heavy weapons, a heavy machine gun equivalent in size and firepower to R-50 caliber.
They had an 82 millimeter mortar, which could fire R-81 millimeter rounds, although you can guess R-81s couldn't fire their 82s.
They had 57-millimeter anti-tank guns in profusion.
They never, to my knowledge, utilized flamethrowers as we did.
They had a lot of knee mortars, or 60-millimeter mortars.
It seems like every squad had a knee mortar.
They had more of the light mortars than we did.
We had given up our combat commands, our infantry companies, after World War II had taken the light mortar away.
And we only had heavy mortars in battalion support.
We had the 81, but it was in our headquarters and support company for each battalion.
Six 81s to a battalion.
They had probably 60 mortars to every one of their companies.
So they had a close...
a heavy weapon at close in.
We had equivalent to that.
We had an M79 grenade launcher, which was an anti-personnel weapon, which we had in every squad.
It wasn't quite as good as the 60 mortar, and later we brought the 60 mortars into our company.
We brought them back and changed the TONE and brought the 60s into every company.

As far as light weapons, again, the AK-47 was popular, although they did have a lot of Browning automatic weapons, BARs, American vintage, .30 caliber M1 Garands, the M1 rifle of World War II vintage.
They had carbines, which was a favorite weapon of theirs, and they had pistols.
Officers normally carried 9mm pistols that were Russian or Chinese or Eastern European.
They had very little in the way of air support.
We had air superiority most of the time.
This particular operation was a clash of major unit size.
They had probably...
Infantry's a majority.
They had greater numbers in men than we did.
We had a superiority in material.
We had more artillery at our beck and call.
We had air strike, air power.
We had vast superiority.
They had no air power whatsoever.
They had their biggest weapon that came into play was a 120 millimeter Russian rocket, which was a pretty lethal weapon, and it was pretty accurate.
Also very frightening coming in by its sound.
I'm forgetting their RPGs, rocket-powered grenades.
They were pretty nasty, too.
We didn't have anything like that.
We had 3.5 rocket launchers, and we had the laws to light anti-tank weapons, which were rocket-powered.
So...
We had weapon superiority.
We had air superiority.
And we could call on naval strength offshore for, again, airstrikes.
And we were operating close enough to the coast that occasionally we could get naval gunfire support.
We had a good supply of artillery.
Armor was not involved because the terrain was not practical for the utilization of armor.
It was a test of infantry, primarily.

uh it got confusing in the very beginning we went in by helicopters helicopters landed all over the place and we were spread out over a huge area as big as bryan college station combined and making this assault we were right at the edge of the dmz the first move that the enemy made was to set fire to the jungle and the elephant grass
which confused us further.
It had the effect of creating an effective smoke screen, as well as the fire blocked our avenues of attack.
And it channeled us up a river valley, which we could walk in the river even though fire was falling on us from trees overhead.
This led to an ambush situation, which we countered.
